questions.text: An ultrasound of a 28-year-old woman with monochorionic-diamniotic twins reveals a significant difference in amniotic fluid levels between the two sacs. Twin A has polyhydramnios, while Twin B has oligohydramnios.  Which of the following symptoms would NOT be found in Twin A?

choices.text: Elevated blood pressure
Increased red blood cell count
Reduced blood volume
Enlarged heart

questions.solution:
Correct answer :C)Reduced blood volume

Explaination :

The above case scenario indicates Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS) seen in monozygotic twins. Hypovolemia is a symptom seen in the donor twin, hypervolemia is a symptom present in the recipient twin. The condition arises from a vascular connection within the shared placenta of the twins

Recipient twin

Donor twin
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Polycythemia
  • Hypertension
  • Hypervolemia
  • Increased risk of congestive heart failure and hydrops
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Anemia
  • Hypotension
  • Hypovolemia

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, presents to your clinic at 20 weeks of gestation for a routine prenatal visit. She mentions increased fatigue, shortness of breath, and noticeable swelling in her legs and feet. On examination, her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and there is no proteinuria. A recent ultrasound confirmed a dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy. Which of the following physiological changes is most likely responsible for her symptoms?

choices.text: Increased cardiac output
Increased peripheral vascular resistance
Decreased blood volume
Reduced glomerular filtration rate

questions.solution:
Correct Answer :A)Increased cardiac output

In twin pregnancies, the maternal cardiovascular system undergoes significant changes to accommodate the increased metabolic demands of both fetuses.

One of the major adaptations is an increase in cardiac output, which can lead to symptoms such as fatigue and shortness of breath. 

Physiological Changes in Twin Pregnancy:

  • Increased Blood Volume: Twin pregnancies are associated with greater blood volume (50 - 60%) than singleton pregnancies (40 - 50%).

  • Decreased Peripheral Vascular Resistance: There is a decrease in PVR compared to singleton pregnancies.

  • Cardiac Output: The cardiac output in twin pregnancies is significantly higher than in singleton pregnancies.

  • Blood Pressure: Despite the increased blood volume and cardiac output, the overall blood pressure in twin pregnancies may not rise proportionally due to the decreased PVR.

  • Pre-eclampsia: Twin pregnancies have a higher incidence of pre-eclampsia. The decreased PVR and increased blood volume can exacerbate the endothelial dysfunction characteristic of pre-eclampsia.

  • Uterine growth in multifetal pregnancies is significantly greater than in singleton pregnancies. Particularly in monozygotic twins, excessive amniotic fluid can accumulate quickly.

  • The expanding uterus can significantly compress and displace the maternal abdominal organs and lungs. In rare cases, maternal renal function may become seriously impaired, likely due to obstructive uropathy.

  • Peripheral vascular resistance decreases in twin pregnancies. (Option B ruled out)
  • The blood volume also expands more than in singleton pregnancies, contributing to peripheral edema. This physiological adaptation ensures adequate blood flow and nutrient delivery to both fetuses. (Option C ruled out)
  • There is increased GFR. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
A 28-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks of gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit in active labor. She is carrying dichorionic diamniotic twins. The first twin is in a cephalic presentation and delivers vaginally without complications. After the delivery of the first twin, the second twin is found to be in a transverse lie. Given the situation, the decision is made to perform an internal podalic version.

Which of the following statements is true regarding internal podalic version in the context of twin pregnancy?

choices.text: It is necessary if the second twin is in a breech presentation.
It involves converting the second twin to a cephalic presentation externally.
It is performed by reaching into the uterus to grasp and bring down the feet of the second twin for a breech delivery.
It is contraindicated in all cases of transverse lie for the second twin.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer : C) It is performed by reaching into the uterus to grasp and bring down the feet of the second twin for a breech delivery.

Internal Podalic Version in Twin Pregnancy: A procedure where a series of manoeuvres are done to reach into the uterus after the delivery of the first twin to grasp the feet of the second twin and convert it from a transverse lie to a breech presentation, allowing for vaginal delivery.

It is necessary if second twin is in breech presentation (Option A), if the second twin is already in a breech presentation, an internal podalic version is not needed.

 

It involves converting the second twin to a cephalic presentation externally(Option B)  as this describes the external cephalic version, not the internal podalic version. Internal podalic version is an internal maneuver.

 

It is contraindicated in all cases of transverse lie for the second twin (Option D): Internal podalic version is not contraindicated in all cases of transverse lie; it is often indicated in such cases, especially in twin pregnancies to facilitate delivery.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation comes for her routine prenatal visit. She is expecting twins, and this is her first pregnancy. An ultrasound performed today shows that the first twin (Twin A) is in a cephalic presentation, while the second twin (Twin B) is in a breech presentation. Both fetuses have normal growth parameters and amniotic fluid indices, and there are no signs of fetal distress. The patient has no significant medical or obstetric history.

What is the most appropriate mode of delivery for this patient?

choices.text: Planned Cesarean section for both twins
Vaginal delivery for both twins, with a possible need for breech extraction for Twin B
Vaginal delivery for Twin A followed by an immediate Cesarean section for Twin B
External cephalic version for Twin B followed by a planned vaginal delivery for both twins

questions.solution:
Correct Answer : B)Vaginal delivery for both twins, with a possible need for breech extraction for Twin B

When the first twin is in cephalic presentation and the second twin is in breech or transverse presentation, normal vaginal delivery is attempted and breech extraction can be done for the second twin.

Mode of Presentation & Delivery

  • Both Cephalic (> 60%) or First Cephalic, 2nd breech/ transverse - Normal vaginal delivery can be done.
  • First Breech, 2nd breech: Cesarean section
  • First Breech, 2nd cephalic: Cesarean section
  • Interlocking of Twins
    • Happens when 1st Twin is in Breech, 2nd Twin is Cephalic
    • Very rarely seen
  • Cord prolapse during twin delivery
    • 1st Twin Cephalic: Delivered
    • 2nd Twin Breech: High station → Cord Prolapse can happen: deliver immediately.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old pregnant woman is undergoing her routine prenatal ultrasound at 18 weeks gestation. The ultrasound reveals she is carrying twins. Further assessment confirms that the twins share a single amniotic sac and a single fused placenta.
Which of the following complications is most specific to this type of twin pregnancy?

choices.text: Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)
Cord entanglement
Selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR)
Preterm labor

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cord entanglement

Explaination:

Monoamniotic twins, who share a single amniotic sac, are at a higher risk for complications such as

  • Cord entanglement due to the lack of a dividing membrane.
  • This is not seen in monochorionic twins with separate amniotic sacs.

Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS) and selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR) (Option A and C ruled out) are complications more commonly associated with monochorionic twin pregnancies, where twins share a placenta.

Selective IUGR (Option D ruled out) is specific to monochorionic twin pregnancy.Monoamniotic twins complications:

  • Cord entanglement
  • Birthweight discordance

Monochorionic twins complications:

  • Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS),
  • Twin anemia–polycythemia sequence (TAPS), and
  • Twin reversed-arterial-perfusion (TRAP) sequence
  • Selective IUGR

 

Complications that occur in both monochorionic and monoamniotic twins:

  • Preterm birth
  • Congenital anomalies

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct statement with respect to selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR)?

choices.text: The fetal weight of one twin is less than the 10th percentile for normal fetuses.
There is a difference in weight of ≥25% between the twins.
Both twins have an unequal share of the placental mass.
MCA Doppler is used as the main modality of diagnosis in sIUGR.

questions.solution:
Correct answer : D ) MCA Doppler is used as the main modality of diagnosis in sIUGR.(Incorrect statement)

  • The main modality for diagnosing sIUGR is the Umbilical artery Doppler, not the middle cerebral artery (MCA) Doppler.

  • The classification and diagnosis of sIUGR involve assessing the characteristics of the umbilical artery Doppler flow for the IUGR fetus.

Selective intrauterine growth restriction (sIUGR) is a condition specific to monochorionic twin pregnancies where one twin exhibits significant growth restriction while the other twin grows normally.

 

  • This disparity in growth is primarily due to unequal placental sharing, resulting in inadequate nutrient and blood supply to the growth-restricted twin.(Option C ruled out)

Key Characteristics of sIUGR:

  1. Fetal Weight Criteria: The fetal weight of one twin is less than the 10th percentile for normal fetuses. (Option A ruled out)
  2. Weight Discrepancy: There is a significant difference in weight (≥25%) between the twins. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis related to the image:

choices.text: Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)
Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence
Twin Anemia Polycythemia Sequence (TAPS)
Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR)

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence

Explanation:

The image shows a typical presentation of Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence, characterized by an acardiac twin, an amorphous mass without a heart, and a normal twin.

  • The acardiac twin receives blood from the normal twin via A-V anastomosis, which can lead to high-output cardiac failure in the normal twin.
  • This deoxygenated blood, which keeps the recipient twin alive, however, goes only to the baby's lower limb, resulting in a mass of flesh with a very small head and properly formed lower limbs.
  • There’s also an impending risk of cardiac failure in the donor baby as it is pumping blood to itself as well as into the recipient baby.
  • Diagnosis is mainly done by USG Doppler or MRI.
  • The main modality of treatment is by ligation of the umbilical cord (laser or RFA) of the acardiac twin under fetoscopic guidance.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old pregnant woman with monochorionic diamniotic twins visits for a routine ultrasound at 32 weeks gestation. There is no significant difference in the weight or amniotic fluid volumes of the twins. Doppler studies show a significant difference in the middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV) between the twins.

What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)
Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence
Twin Anemia Polycythemia Sequence (TAPS)
Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Twin Anemia Polycythemia Sequence (TAPS)

Explanation:

  • Twin Anemia Polycythemia Sequence (TAPS) is diagnosed using Fetal Doppler based on a significant difference in MCA PSV between the twins (Donor twin has an MCA PSV of >1.5 MoM, and the recipient twin has an MCA PSV of <1.0 MoM), without significant differences in their weight or amniotic fluid volumes.
  • TAPS occurs due to unbalanced feto-fetal transfusion through minuscule placental anastomoses in monochorionic twin pregnancies, leading to Hb difference of ≥ 5gm % between the two twins.

Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS) (Option A) typically involves significant differences in amniotic fluid volumes between the twins, with one twin having polyhydramnios and the other having oligohydramnios.

Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP) Sequence (Option B) involves an acardiac twin that is perfused by the pump twin, leading to reversed blood flow and a different clinical presentation.

Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) (Option D) involves significant growth restriction without the specific Doppler findings of differing MCA PSV seen in TAPS.

questions.text: All of the following can be management options for complicated cases of TTTS except?

choices.text: Laser ablation of deep arteriovenous anastomosis
Amnioreduction in the recipient twin
Single fetal reduction of the recipient twin
Septostomy

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Single fetal reduction of the recipient twin

Explanation:

Single fetal reduction is generally considered for the donor twin in the management of Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS), so as to improve the survival chances of the recipient twin.

Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

Definition
  • TTTS is characterized by deep AV anastomosis between monochorionic twins.
  • More common in MCDA>MCMA

Clinical Findings
  • Donor Twin: Oligohydramnios (<2 cm), anemia, hypovolemia, hypotension, growth restriction, "stuck" appearance.
  • Recipient Twin: Polyhydramnios (>8 cm), polycythemia, hypervolemia, hypertension, larger size, risk of heart failure and hydrops fetalis.

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Ultrasound Findings: MCDA twin pregnancy, discrepant amniotic fluid volumes, size discrepancy.
  • Doppler Studies: Abnormal blood flow patterns, such as absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the donor twin's umbilical artery.
  • Hematologic Findings: Hemoglobin difference >5 g%, estimated fetal weight discrepancy >25%.

Management

(Option A, B and D)
  • Laser Ablation
  • Amnioreduction
  • Septostomy
  • Selective Reduction of donor twin

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Quintero staging system for Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)?

choices.text: Stage I is characterized by absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery of the donor twin.
Stage II is defined by the presence of polyhydramnios in the recipient twin and anhydramnios in the donor twin.
Stage III involves critically abnormal Doppler findings in one or both twins.
Stage V indicates the presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer :C) Stage III involves critically abnormal Doppler findings in one or both twins.

According to Quintero Staging System for TTTS, Stage III indicates presence of abnormal doppler findings in one of both twins, such as

  • Absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery,
  • Reversed flow in the ductus venosus
  • Pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein.


 

Quintero Staging System for Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

Stage

Description

Stage I (Option A ruled out)

Polyhydramnios in the recipient twin (deepest vertical pocket ≥8 cm) and oligohydramnios in the donor twin (deepest vertical pocket ≤2 cm), with a visible bladder in the donor twin.

Stage II (Option B ruled out)

The donor twin's bladder is not visible on ultrasound, indicating severe oligohydramnios.

Stage III

Critically abnormal Doppler findings, such as absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery, reversed flow in the ductus venosus, or pulsatile flow in the umbilical vein in one or both twins

Stage IV

Presence of hydrops fetalis in one or both twins, indicating severe fetal compromise

Stage V (Option D ruled out)

Demise of one or both twins

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding multifetal pregnancy, except:

choices.text: Hellin's rule states that the incidence of twins is approximately 1 in 80 pregnancies.
Advanced maternal age increases the likelihood of multifetal pregnancy.
The use of fertility treatments can elevate the risk of multifetal pregnancy.
Multifetal pregnancies are associated with decreased risk of preterm birth.

questions.solution:
Multifetal pregnancies actually have a higher risk of preterm birth. Main causes include:

  • Overstretched uterus
  • Excess amniotic fluid
  • Early rupture of membrane

 

According to Hellin’s rule:

  • The incidence of twins is approximately 1 in 80 pregnancies.
  • The incidence of triplets is approximately 1 in 80² (1 in 6,400) pregnancies.
  • The incidence of quadruplets is approximately 1 in 80³ (1 in 512,000) pregnancies, and so on (Option A ruled out).

Older maternal age, particularly over 35, is associated with an increased likelihood of multifetal pregnancy, often due to increased ovulation of multiple eggs (Option B ruled out).

Fertility treatments such as ovulation induction and in vitro fertilization significantly increase the chances of multifetal pregnancies (Option C ruled out).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman pregnant with monochorionic-diamniotic twins presents for a routine ultrasound. The ultrasound reveals no cardiac activity in one of the twins. The other twin has normal cardiac activity. Which of the following is a major complication in the surviving twin?

choices.text: Oligohydramnios
Cerebral palsy
Anemia
Hypotension

questions.solution:
Correcr Answer :B)Cerebral palsy

Explaination:

Cerebral palsy is one of the major complications seen in the surviving twin in Single fetal demise. Other complications include:

  • Multicystic encephalomalacia

  • Microcephaly

  • renal cortical necrosis

  • DIC

 

This is likely due to the passage of thromboplastin from the deceased twin to the surviving twin via placental anastomoses and trigger a serious reaction.

 

Oligohydramnios, Anemia, and Hypotension are the complications seen in Donor Twin in Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome. (Option A, C, D ruled out)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of inability to conceive , presents at 12 weeks gestation following her first IVF cycle. Ultrasound confirms a quadruplet pregnancy. The doctor discusses multifetal reduction. Which of the following statements regarding fetal reduction is FALSE?

choices.text: Improves the overall perinatal outcome in quadruplets
Potassium chloride is used in fetal reduction
Performed between 11 and 13 weeks of gestation
Monochorionic twin pregnancies are ideally suited for fetal reduction procedures

questions.solution:
Correct answer :D) Monochorionic twin pregnancies are ideally suited for fetal reduction procedures

Explanation 

Monochorionic twin pregnancies pose significant challenges for fetal reduction due to the shared placenta and potential vascular connections between the twins, making them less ideal candidates for this procedure.

  • In this scenario to improve the outcomes for the remaining fetuses, a selective reduction procedure may be performed to reduce the number of fetuses to two. This procedure is typically done between 11 and 13 weeks of pregnancy. (Option A, C ruled out)
  • Selective fetal reduction is a procedure commonly used in multifetal pregnancies of higher order (3 or more) .
  • Fetal reduction can be performed by injecting potassium chloride into the heart of the targeted fetus under ultrasound guidance. The procedure is transabdominal.(Option B ruled out)
  • To protect the co-twin from the potential adverse effects of potassium chloride, the umbilical cord of the targeted twin is occluded. This can be done by fetoscopic ligation, laser, or bipolar coagulation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Some degree of discordant growth is normal in dizygotic twins
Intrauterine death of one fetus is more in dizygotic twins
Fetal anomalies are more commonly seen in dizygotic twins
Fetal complications in multifetal pregnancy doesn't depend on chorionicity

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Some degree of discordant growth is normal in dizygotic twins

Explanation:

 

Discordant twin growth is a common complication of multifetal pregnancy. An estimated weight difference of 25% or more is considered true pathological discordance. Some degree of discordant growth is normal in dizygotic twins. Discordance may be due to twin-twin transfusion syndrome, placental insufficiency, IUGR, or structural anomalies occurring in one fetus.

Foetal Complications in Multifetal Pregnancies

Increased Miscarriage Rate

More common in monozygotic twins.

High Premature Birth Rate

80% occurrence, with associated risks.

Discordant Twin Growth
  • 20% prevalence, with pathological discordance (≥25% weight difference).
  • Causes: Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), placental insufficiency, intrauterine growth restriction, structural anomalies.

Increased Intrauterine Foetal Death
  • More common in monozygotic twins. (Option B ruled out)
  • First Trimester: Vanishing twin through resorption.
  • Second Trimester: Fetus papyraceous (mummified foetus).
  • Late Pregnancy: Risks to surviving twin or maternal disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Appearing Twin Phenomenon

A twin initially missed on ultrasound but detected later, more common in monozygotic twins.

Increased Foetal Anomalies
  • 2-4% higher risk in monozygous twins than in singleton pregnancies. (Option C ruled out)
  • Includes anencephaly, holoprosencephaly, neural tube defects, symmelia, microcephaly, cardiac anomalies and Down’s syndrome.

Higher Risk of Asphyxia and Stillbirth
  • Increased risk due to pre-eclampsia, malpresentation, placental abruption, and operative interventions.
  • The second twin is at higher risk.

Specific Complications in Monozygotic/Monochorionic Twins:

Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

Occurs in 10-15% of monozygotic twins due to placental vascular anastomosis.

Dead Foetus Syndrome

2-7% occurrence, with a 25% risk of poor outcomes for the surviving twin.

Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion (TRAP)

High risk of perinatal death from cardiac failure in the healthy twin; chromosomal abnormalities in the perfused twin.

Monoamniotic Twins

High perinatal mortality due to cord entanglement, low birth weight and congenital anomalies.

 

Fetal complications in multifetal pregnancy are more in the monochorionic type as compared to dichorionic, thus depend on chorionicity (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman at 28 weeks gestation, conceived via in vitro fertilization (IVF) is now carrying dichorionic-diamniotic twins. She reports increasing discomfort and shortness of breath over the past few weeks. Fetal heart rates are within normal limits. Which of the following is the least likely complication in her pregnancy ?

choices.text: Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome
Preterm labor
Pre-eclampsia
Malpresentation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome .

Explanation:

Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS) is a complication specific to monochorionic twins (not DCDA) due to sharing of placenta & in those with problematic deep arterio-venous connections between the placentas. Such connections are more often encountered in MCDA twins rather than MCMA twins.

Maternal Complications can be divided into 3 stages:

  • Pregnancy
  • Labor
  • Puerperium

 

Pregnancy

Labor

Puerperium
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Anemia
  • PIH and pre-eclampsia
  • Polyhydramnios/ oligohydramnios
  • Preterm labor
  • Malpresentation
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Mechanical distress (dyspnea, palpitation)
  • Prolonged labor
  • Operative interference
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Subinvolution
  • Infection
  • Lactation failure

 

Preterm labor (Option B ) occurs frequently (in 50% of cases) in twin pregnancies, with twins typically being delivered around 37 weeks gestation on average. The causes include excessive stretching of the uterus, increased amniotic fluid (hydramnios), and premature rupture of membranes

 

Pre-eclampsia (Option C): The risk is three times higher in twin pregnancies, possibly due to increased exposure to an excess of chorionic villi 

 

Malpresentation (Option D) is more frequent in twins compared to single pregnancies. Approximately 70% of the time, the first baby presents headfirst (vertex), and in 50% of cases, both babies present headfirst. Therefore, malpresentation is more commonly observed in the second baby

questions.text: During a chorionicity scan in a twin pregnancy, which imaging finding would indicate Monochorionic-Monoamniotic (MCMA) twins?

choices.text: Visualization of two distinct placentas and separate amniotic sacs
Detection of a single placenta and two separate amniotic sacs
Identification of a single placenta and a single shared amniotic sac
Observation of two placentas and a single shared amniotic sac

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Identification of a single placenta and a single shared amniotic sac

Explanation:

Identification of a single placenta and a single shared amniotic sac indicates a Monochorionic-monoamniotic pregnancy as MCMA twins share both the placenta and the amniotic sac.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound (TVS) at 11–14 weeks of gestation. 

A. ‘Twin peak’ sign: In dichorionic diamniotic twin gestations, the chorion and amnion for each twin reflect away from the fused placenta to form the intertwin membrane. A potential space exists in the intertwin membrane, filled by proliferating placental villi giving rise to the twin peak sign. The twin peak sign appears as a triangle with the base at the chorionic surface and the apex in the intertwin membrane.

B. In monochorionic, diamniotic twins, the intertwin membrane only comprises two amnions.

 

 

C. Color Doppler scan (TVS) showing twin pregnancy. A thick intertwin membrane (twin peak sign) of the dichorionic, diamniotic placenta is seen.

  • This finding indicates a Dichorionic-Diamniotic (DCDA) twin pregnancy, where each twin has its own placenta and amniotic sac.(Option A ruled out)
  • This describes a Monochorionic-Diamniotic (MCDA) twin pregnancy, where twins share a placenta but have separate amniotic sacs.(Option B ruled out)
  • This scenario is not physiologically possible in twin pregnancies; twins cannot share a single amniotic sac if they have separate placentas.(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between Dichorionic-Diamniotic (DCDA), Monochorionic-Diamniotic (MCDA), and Monochorionic-Monoamniotic (MCMA) twins?

choices.text: DCDA twins each have their own chorion and amnion, while MCDA twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs, and MCMA twins share both a chorion and an amnion.
DCDA twins share a chorion and an amnion, MCDA twins each have their own chorion but share an amnion, and MCMA twins have separate chorions and amniotic sacs.
MCDA twins have separate placentas and amniotic sacs, DCDA twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs, and MCMA twins share both chorion and amnion.
MCMA twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs, DCDA twins each have their own chorion and amnion, and MCDA twins share both chorion and amnion.

questions.solution:
Option a) DCDA twins develop from an early split (within the first 3 days) resulting in each twin having its own chorion and amnion. MCDA twins split later (between 4-7 days) and share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs. MCMA twins result from a later split (between 8-12 days), sharing both the chorion and amnion.

 

Timing of Cleavage

Placenta & Membrane Status

< 72 hours

Dichorionic-Diamniotic twins each have their own separate placenta and amniotic sac.

Days 4–7

Monochorionic-Diamniotic twins share one placenta (chorion) but have separate amniotic sacs.

Days 8–12

Monochorionic-Monoamniotic twins share both the placenta and the amniotic sac.

questions.text: Which type of monozygotic twins develops when the zygote splits very early, usually within the first 3 days after fertilization, resulting in separate placentas and amniotic sacs for each twin?

choices.text: Monochorionic-diamniotic twins
Monochorionic-monoamniotic twins
Dichorionic-diamniotic twins
Conjoined twins

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Dichorionic-diamniotic twins

Explanation:

Dichorionic-Diamniotic twins each have their own separate placenta and amniotic sac, forming when the zygote splits early, typically within the first 3 days after fertilization.

Zygosity

Chorionicity

Zygosity refers to the genetic makeup of twin pregnancies. Monozygotic twins originate from a single fertilized egg that splits into two, leading to genetically identical individuals.

Chorionicity refers to the placenta’s membrane status. Chorionicity is determined by the timing of embryo division.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes superfetation in the context of twin formation?

choices.text: The fertilization of two ova released during the same menstrual cycle, possibly resulting in twins of the same gestational age but different fathers.
The occurrence of a second pregnancy while already carrying a fetus, leading to twins of different gestational ages.
The fertilization of a single ovum by two different sperm cells, resulting in a rare form of identical twins.
The splitting of a single fertilized egg into two embryos, leading to identical twins of the same gestational age.

questions.solution:
Superfetation involves the fertilization of a new ovum and implantation during an existing pregnancy, resulting in twins with different gestational ages.

  •  Heteropaternal superfecundation occurs when two eggs from the same cycle are fertilized by sperm from different instances of intercourse. (Option A ruled out)
  •  The fertilization of a single ovum by two different sperm cells is an extremely rare phenomenon known as sesquizygotic twinning or heterogynic twinning.  (Option C ruled out)
  • Monozygotic or identical twins, where a single fertilized egg divides into two embryos, not related to superfetation. (Option D ruled out)
